    <item>
      <title><![CDATA[Budget 2026: EY for tax certainty as Budget nears, awaits rules & proposes amendments to New Income Tax Act]]></title>

      <description><![CDATA[Max Estates CFO Nitin Kansal said the company is on track to achieve ₹6,000–6,500 crore in sales bookings, with most launches planned for the second half of the year. He said NCR markets are seeing a shift from rapid price increases to steady growth, with Noida and Gurugram showing different demand trends.     <item>
      <title><![CDATA[Ageing with Dignity: The Antara Senior Care Story ]]></title>
      <link><![CDATA[https://www.cnbctv18.com/access/watchlist/business/ageing-with-dignity-the-antara-senior-care-story-19812512.htm]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[India is ageing fast. Seniors already account for 11% of the population. By 2050, that share will double to 21% - meaning one in every five Indians will be aged above 60. With longer lifespans, shrinking family units and dual-income households, one truth is clear: More seniors will age alone and with more complex care needs than ever before. On Young Turks Reloaded, Shereen Bhan speaks with Tara Singh Vachani, Executive Chairperson of Antara Senior Care, a company that's determined to reshape how India thinks about ageing and elder care.She recalls Antara’s early years, battling stigma and misconception, when senior care facilities were perceived as aid to abandonment. But now, the mindset has evolved, especially after the pandemic. “People have started believing in wellness a lot more. They have understood that, as they get older, they need an ecosystem to support them,” Tara shares. Today, 60-year-olds are redefining retirement. It’s no longer just about grandchildren and slowing down. They are embracing self-care without guilt - a shift also powered by India’s economic prosperity, which allows seniors to prioritise their own needs while fulfilling obligations to their families. And while the world is busy trying to ‘hack longevity’, Tara believes the focus must be on living well. As she puts it, Antara’s mission is 'to make the years that you are alive as joyful, as healthy, and as happy as possible'.India is ageing fast. Seniors already account for 11% of the population. By 2050, that share will double to 21% - meaning one in every five Indians will be aged above 60. With longer lifespans, shrinking family units and dual-income households, one truth is clear: More seniors will age alone and with more complex care needs than ever before. On Young Turks Reloaded, Shereen Bhan speaks with Tara Singh Vachani, Executive Chairperson of Antara Senior Care, a company that's determined to reshape how India thinks about ageing and elder care.She recalls Antara’s early years, battling stigma and misconception, when senior care facilities were perceived as aid to abandonment. But now, the mindset has evolved, especially after the pandemic. “People have started believing in wellness a lot more. They have understood that, as they get older, they need an ecosystem to support them,” Tara shares. Today, 60-year-olds are redefining retirement. It’s no longer just about grandchildren and slowing down. They are embracing self-care without guilt - a shift also powered by India’s economic prosperity, which allows seniors to prioritise their own needs while fulfilling obligations to their families. And while the world is busy trying to ‘hack longevity’, Tara believes the focus must be on living well. As she puts it, Antara’s mission is 'to make the years that you are alive as joyful, as healthy, and as happy as possible'.]]></description>
      <pubDate><![CDATA[Fri, 2 Jan 2026 12:29:58 +0530]]></pubDate>
      <dc:creator>Shreya Chandra</dc:creator>
      <guid><![CDATA[https://www.cnbctv18.com/access/watchlist/business/ageing-with-dignity-the-antara-senior-care-story-19812512.htm]]></guid>
